Award.AwardTitle: Correlating Local Defect Structure with Dynamical Response in Graphene

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to correlate the local, atomic-scale structure of graphene nanoresonators with their non-local oscillatory response at high driving frequencies. This will be performed by combining high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy with high frequency opto-electric actuation techniques to probe suspended graphene membranes. We will investigate clamped, suspended membranes having diameters down to 25 nm, a regime that has so far been inaccessible to dynamical measurement. Using a combination of ion irradiation, high energy electrons, and adsorbate deposition, we will control and characterize specific defect and adsorbate configurations of graphene nanoresonators and monitor how this affects their resonant and dissipative behavior. The nonlinear tunnel current of a scanning tunneling microscope will be used here in a new rectifying mode that will serve as a sensitive probe of high frequency surface oscillatory amplitude and spatial eigenmodes. This will provide a powerful new tool for testing multi-scale theoretical models that combine atomistically defined defect configurations with continuum material properties.

This research will explore new physical phenomena that have been predicted but never before observed, such as the effect of specific defect configurations on the dynamical susceptibility of strained, suspended graphene nanoresonators. The research will enable an entirely new technique of microscopy that marries atomic-scale spatial resolution with high-frequency dynamical characterization. This will facilitate the exploration of nanostructure processes and behavior that were previously inaccessible due to a lack of tools for simultaneously measuring the atomic scale properties and oscillatory response of individual clamped graphene nanoresonators. The potential impact on technology is strong, since this work should result in new types of nanoresonators that will be applicable in the areas of nano-electronics, communications, chemical detection, mass sensing, charge sensing, probing quantum fluctuations, and general exploration of elastic behavior at the atomic scale. The impact on education and outreach will also be strong. This project will provide scientific training to graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students in a strongly interdisciplinary area

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at exploring how the atomic-scale structure of two-dimensional (2D) materials influences how they respond to light and mechanical excitation. The project had significant intellectual merit because it provided new insight into the fundamental physical properties of new 2D materials in different environments and in new device configurations.  The study of 2D materials is an exciting topic in condensed matter physics and material science because the properties of 2D materials can differ significantly (and in useful ways) from the properties of conventional 3D materials that have much greater thickness. Part of the reason for this is that electrons move differently when they are highly confined in the third dimension of a material. This has significant consequences for the mechanical properties of 2D materials, as well as how they respond to light.

            Our strategy for this program was to build electrical devices from new 2D materials, to use powerful microscopy to measure their fundamental properties at the atomic scale, to actuate 2D devices with light, and to develop new ways to mechanically tune these devices so as to access new physical phenomena.  Using novel experimental techniques, we were able to image individual defects (i.e., imperfections) in 2D devices and to gain useful new insight into how electrical charge jumps into and out of such defects in response to changing the operating parameters of the device. We were also able to explore individual molecules in these devices for the first time. We directly measured how the vibrations of molecules that are attached to a 2D device affect how the device behaves, and we showed that we can tune this behavior by adding electrical charge to the molecules. We were additionally able to measure how shining light on 2D materials changes their properties. By combining optical measurements with sensitive microscopy we were able to directly measure how electrons in 2D materials pull back into their original positions after they are rearranged by absorbing the energy of a single photon of light (this property is called the “exciton binding energy”).

            This project also allowed us to make important progress in exploring a new type of 2D device that can be modified in a very unique way. While most devices are static in the sense that their basic properties can’t be changed once they are built, this new type of device has an “active element” that can be reconfigured by an outside stimulus. We achieved this by bonding 2D materials to active substrates that can be modified externally. One such active substrate is SiO2, which can be made to expand locally by injecting it with a focused beam of charged helium atoms.  We studied how the expanding SiO2 substrate stretches the 2D membrane on top, thus changing its properties in interesting ways. We also studied what happens when 2D materials are bonded to an organic polymer layer. We discovered that 2D materials completely change the properties of organic layers by strengthening them in unexpected ways that could be useful in future applications.

            The broader impact of this work lies in how it will affect the scientific and engineering communities of our nation, as well as in the effects of the educational and outreach activities that we performed. The work performed in this project will aid in the development of future applications involving the use of 2D materials as exquisite sensors that are more flexible and sensitive than current technologies.
